Case Study: Expansion of Fcγ Receptor IIIa-Positive Macrophages, Ficolin 1-Positive Monocyte-Derived Dendritic Cells, and Plasmacytoid Dendritic Cells Associated With Severe Skin Disease in Systemic Sclerosis

Kayla Interdonanto

Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center
Kayla.Morrell@RoswellPark.org

1 November 2022

Source: vignettes/hca-7f351a4c-d24c-4fcd-9040-f79071b097d0.Rmd
hca-7f351a4c-d24c-4fcd-9040-f79071b097d0.Rmd

Setup

Load useful packages

library(HCACaseStudies)
library(hca)
library(dplyr)

Project information

Set the project id

project_id <- "7f351a4c-d24c-4fcd-9040-f79071b097d0"

Display information about the project

project_information(project_id)
## Title
##   Expansion of Fcγ Receptor IIIa-Positive Macrophages, Ficolin
##   1-Positive Monocyte-Derived Dendritic Cells, and Plasmacytoid
##   Dendritic Cells Associated With Severe Skin Disease in Systemic
##   Sclerosis
## Contributors (unknown order; any role)
##   Robyn T Domsic, Christina Morse, Dan Xue, Dinesh Khanna, Ida Zucchi,
##   Yi Yang, Robert Lafyatis, Tracy Tabib
## Description
##   Objective. We sought a comprehensive understanding of myeloid cell
##   types driving fibrosis in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis
##   (dcSSc) skin. Methods. We analyzed the transcriptomes of 2,465
##   myeloid cells skin biopsies from 10 healthy controls (HCs) and 12
##   dcSSc patients by single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq). Monocyte-
##   derived dendritic cells were stained by immunohistochemistry and
##   immunofluorescence targeting FCN1. Results. T-stochastic neighbor
##   embedding analysis of single cell transcriptome data revealed 12
##   myeloid cell clusters, nine of which paralleled previously described
##   HC Mφ/DC clusters and three of which were dcSSc-specific myeloid cell
##   clusters. One SSc-associated macrophage cluster, highly expressing
##   FCGR3A, on pseudotime analysis was suggested to derive from normal
##   CCR1+ and MARCO+ macrophages. A second SSc-associated myeloid
##   population, highly expressed monocyte markers: FCN1, EREG, S100A8 and
##   S100A9, but was closely related to cDC2 on pseudotime analysis and
##   identified as Mo-DC. Mo-DC were associated with more severe skin
##   disease. Proliferating macrophages and plasmacytoid dendritic cells
##   were detected almost exclusively in dcSSc skin, the latter clustering
##   with B cells and apparently derived from lymphoid progenitors.
##   Conclusions. Transcriptional signatures in these and other myeloid
##   populations indicate innate immune activation, possibly through TLRs,
##   and highly upregulated chemokines. However, the appearance and
##   activation of myeloid cells is variable between patients, indicating
##   differing underlying pathogenesis and/or temporal disease activity.
## DOI
##   10.1002/art.41813
## URL
##   https://doi.org/10.1002/art.41813
## Project
##   https://data.humancellatlas.org/explore/projects/7f351a4c-d24c-4fcd-9040-f79071b097d0

Conventions

Statistics calculated locally use local.* for column names, e.g., local.cellCount.

Data processing

Project & samples

Create a filter to identify the project

project_filter <- filters(projectId = list(is = project_id))

Find the project

p <- projects(project_filter, as = "tibble_expanded")
p |> glimpse()

Samples associated with the project

s <- samples(project_filter, as = "tibble_expanded")

Columns are either variable and therefore describe sample-level information…

## informative 'specimen' or 'donorOrganisms' columns
s |>
    select(starts_with("specimens") | starts_with("donorOrganisms")) |>
    select(where(column_is_informative)) |>
    glimpse()
## Rows: 22
## Columns: 7
## $ specimens.disease                <chr> "normal", "normal", "diffuse cutaneou…
## $ specimens.id                     <chr> "SC4_skin_sample", "SC18_skin_sample"…
## $ donorOrganisms.biologicalSex     <chr> "male", "female", "female", "male", "…
## $ donorOrganisms.disease           <chr> "normal", "normal", "diffuse cutaneou…
## $ donorOrganisms.id                <chr> "SC4", "SC18", "SC86", "SC34", "SC185…
## $ donorOrganisms.organismAge.value <chr> "54", "66", "40", "24", "41", "62", "…
## $ donorOrganisms.organismAgeRange  <list> <1702944000, 1702944000>, <208137600…

…or invariant and reflect experiment-wide annotation

s |>
    select(where(column_is_experimentwide)) |>
    distinct() |>
    glimpse()

Data files

What types of files does the project have?

files1 <- files(project_filter)

files1 |>
    glimpse()
## Rows: 340
## Columns: 8
## $ fileId       <chr> "6b6ce27b-80a5-46c6-b275-fa5170fb7a71", "f40d86d8-fe93-45…

## $ projectTitle <chr> "Expansion of Fcγ Receptor IIIa-Positive Macrophages, Fic…
## $ projectId    <chr> "7f351a4c-d24c-4fcd-9040-f79071b097d0", "7f351a4c-d24c-4f…
## $ url          <chr> "https://service.azul.data.humancellatlas.org/repository/…

files1 |>
    count(fileFormat)
## # A tibble: 2 × 2
##   fileFormat     n
##   <chr>      <int>
## 1 fastq.gz     318
## 2 h5            22

There are 318 fastq files, but no summaries, so count matrices cannot be easily constructed.

Row, sample, and cell annotations

We don’t have any information on row data.

row_data <- tibble()

Column (sample & cell) data

sample_data <-
    ## from the hca sample annotation...
    s |>
    select(
        where(column_is_informative) & where(is.atomic)
    )

sample_data
## # A tibble: 22 × 13
##    entryId       dates…¹ dates…² dates…³ donor…⁴ donor…⁵ donor…⁶ donor…⁷ proto…⁸

We don’t have any cell data.

Experiment-wide metadata 

sample_metadata <-
    s |>
    select(where(column_is_experimentwide) & !any_of(names(p))) |>
    distinct()

metadata <- bind_cols(p, sample_metadata)

metadata |>
    glimpse()

Anomalies

When running files() only fastq files were found. But looking on the website there are 22 .h5 files that contain count matrix information that were contributor generated. How come these files weren’t found?
